questions.question_text: Which two steps must an administrator take in order to deploy an instance of Azure VMware Solutions? (Choose two.)

choices.E: Deploy and Configure Microsoft Azure ExpressRoute.
choices.B: Deploy and configure Microsoft Enterprise Edge (MSEE) appliances.
choices.C: Create a support request with VMware Support to create a private cloud.
choices.D: Associate the subscription with a Microsoft Enterprise Agreement.
choices.A: Create a support request with Microsoft Azure Support to create a host quota.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
Let's break down why the other options are not required for initial deployment:

B. Deploy and configure Microsoft Enterprise Edge (MSEE) appliances: MSEE appliances are typically used for hybrid cloud connectivity scenarios and not strictly mandatory for deploying a basic Azure VMware Solution private cloud.
C. Create a support request with VMware Support to create a private cloud: While VMware provides support for Azure VMware Solutions, creating the private cloud itself happens through Azure portal or Azure CLI, not requiring direct involvement from VMware Support.
E. Deploy and Configure Microsoft Azure ExpressRoute: ExpressRoute allows private connections to Azure, but it's not essential for initial deployment. You can utilize the public internet for initial configuration and later establish ExpressRoute for enhanced security or performance.

Selected Answer: AD
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-vmware/plan-private-cloud-deployment#identify-the-subscription

 --> Identify the Azure subscription, resource group, region, and resource name
(The subscription must be associated with a Microsoft Enterprise Agreement (EA), a Cloud Solution Provider (CSP) Azure plan, or a Microsoft Customer Agreement (MCA)
and then:
 Identify the size hosts and determine the number of clusters and hosts
 --> Request a host quota for an eligible Azure plan
 Identify the /22 CIDR IP segment for private cloud management
 Identify a single network segment
 Define the virtual network gateway
 Define VMware HCX network segments

Selected Answer: AB
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-vmware/introduction
Get AV36, AV36P, or AV52, and AV64 quota approval from Microsoft with a minimum of three nodes each.

Each Azure VMware Solution environment is its own ExpressRoute region (its own virtual MSEE device), which lets you connect Global Reach to the 'local' peering location. It allows you to connect multiple Azure VMware Solution instances in one region to the same peering location.

Selected Answer: AD
You need to request a quote (A) and you need to associate a subscription (D).
A & E appear to be correct.

comments.content: There is no info about an onprem-connetion of the Azure VPC, so no E

discussion.content:
Azure VMware Solution (AVS) is a service provided by Microsoft in partnership with VMware that enables users to run VMware workloads natively on Azure. To set up an Azure VMware Solution instance:

A. Before deploying the Azure VMware Solution private cloud, a host quota is required. The user must create a support request with Microsoft Azure Support to increase the quota for Azure VMware Solution hosts in the chosen region.

E. Azure VMware Solution requires an ExpressRoute circuit to connect to the on-premises network. ExpressRoute provides a dedicated and private connection between the user's on-premises infrastructure and Azure.

The other options listed are not required for the deployment of an Azure VMware Solution instance.
It's D and E. You request a host quota during your planning phase, the MSEE devices are associated with the Azure ExpressRoute configuration, and you don't Create a support request with VMware.

Selected Answer: AD
I think the model answer AD is correct, see this Microsoft KB on setting up Azure VMware solution
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-vmware/plan-private-cloud-deployment#request-a-host-quota

Sorry, should till have been DE:)

D: Register the Microsoft.AVS resource provider = Associate the subscription with a Microsoft Enterprise Agreement.
E: Connect to a new or existing ExpressRoute virtual network gateway = Deploy and Configure Microsoft Azure ExpressRoute.

BD :) https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-vmware/deploy-azure-vmware-solution?tabs=azure-portal

Register the resource provider and create a private cloud
Connect to a new or existing ExpressRoute virtual network gateway
Validate the network connect

D: Register the Microsoft.AVS resource provider = Associate the subscription with a Microsoft Enterprise Agreement.

B: Connect to a new or existing ExpressRoute virtual network gateway = Deploy and configure Microsoft Enterprise Edge (MSEE) appliances.

comments.content: Think I might be wrong. BE ?

discussion.content: Pretty sure you need to create a support request!?

Selected Answer: BD
I think BD are correct

questions.question_text: When configuring Hybrid Linked Mode, what is the maximum supported latency between an on-premises environment and a VMware Cloud on AWS software-defined data center (SDDC)?

discussion.content: D, 100ms RTT
D is the right answer!

Selected Answer: D
D is the correct answer.

The maximum latency between your cloud SDDC and on-premises data center cannot exceed 100 msec roundtrip

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Cloud-on-AWS/services/com.vmware.vsphere.vmc-aws-manage-data-center-vms.doc/GUID-BE75F0F1-2864-4926-97FE-37E635471C43.html#:~:text=The%20maximum%20latency%20between%20your,will%20have%20Cloud%20Administrator%20permissions.

D is correct 

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Cloud-on-AWS/services/com.vmware.vsphere.vmc-aws-manage-data-center-vms.doc/GUID-BE75F0F1-2864-4926-97FE-37E635471C43.html

questions.question_text:
A cloud administrator is asked to configure access to the VMware Cloud Services Console based on the following requirement:
Groups and users should be synchronized from the internal Active Directory
Which two options should the administrator configure to meet this requirement? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
A. Workspace ONE Access connector
D. Enterprise federation with connector-based authentication setup

Selected Answer: AD
C. SAML 2.0 Identity Provider: This is the core identity provider technology that allows the VMware Cloud Services Console to trust authentication requests coming from your organization's Active Directory.
D. Enterprise federation with connector-based authentication setup: This specific type of enterprise federation leverages a Workspace ONE Access connector to synchronize user and group information from your Active Directory to the VMware Cloud Services Console.

Terribly worded Q&A, or at least very out-of-date. Multiple possible answers depending on whether you choose Dynamic (connectorless) authentication setup OR Connector-based authentication setup. See page 4 of 
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Cloud-services/services/setting-up-enterprise-federation-cloud-services.pdf

A. Workspace ONE Access connector
D. Enterprise federation with connector-based authentication setup

Explanation:
To synchronize groups and users from the internal Active Directory to the VMware Cloud Services Console, the administrator should:

A. Deploy a Workspace ONE Access connector. This connector integrates with the on-premises Active Directory to synchronize users and/or groups to Workspace ONE Access.

D. Set up Enterprise federation with connector-based authentication. This setup uses the Workspace ONE Access connector to authenticate and sync users/groups from the on-premises Active Directory.

The other options listed are not specifically required for this synchronization and authentication requirement.

comments.content: its a discussion if you think they are correct state your reasoning

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
AC are correct

choices.D: Enterprise federation with connector-based authentication setup
choices.B: Enterprise federation with dynamic (connectorless) authentication setup

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
A. Configure segment DHCP ip-helper: An IP helper points to a specific DHCP server within the SDDC itself. This wouldn't be appropriate if you want to utilize an external corporate DHCP server.
B. Create a DHCP server profile: While creating a DHCP server profile is useful for deploying a DHCP server within the SDDC, it's not necessary when using an external corporate DHCP server.
C. Attach segment to Tier-0 gateway: Tier-0 gateways typically handle east-west traffic within the SDDC. For DHCP relay to an external server, attaching the segment to the Tier-1 gateway is more appropriate.

Selected Answer: D
Question said: "corporate DHCP server" - so DHCP already EXISTS. B for sure incorrect. We need to create DHCP relay profile (which contains corp DHCP server IP) and attach to segment. We do this normally at Tier-1 GW (not T0) with NSX 4.x

Key thing here is VMC uses relay profile, so answer is D, you can't configure the T0 gw.
https://blogs.vmware.com/cloud/2019/07/02/dhcp-dhcp-relay-vmware-cloud-aws/

correction : A. 1. Create a new segment attached to the Tier-0 gateway
2. Configure the segment DHCP ip-helper

Explanation:
When you want a segment in the VMware NSX environment to utilize an external DHCP server, you need to create the segment and then set the DHCP relay, which is the DHCP ip-helper. This tells the segment to relay DHCP requests to a specific external DHCP server. In most cases, this would be done on segments attached to the Tier-0 gateway when you're intending to use an external DHCP server.
D is correct a relay is required

Selected Answer: D
you dont have access to T0 ... and it's a Relay not a server profile

choices.C:
1. Create a new segment attached to the Tier-1 gateway
2. Configure the segment DHCP ip-helper
choices.D:
1. Create a DHCP relay profile
2. Create a new segment attached to the Tier-1 gateway
3. Configure the segment DHCP config to utilize the new DHCP relay profile
choices.B:
1. Create a DHCP server profile
2. Create a new segment attached to the Tier-0 gateway
3. Configure the segment DHCP config to utilize the new DHCP server profile
choices.A:
1. Create a new segment attached to the Tier-0 gateway
2. Configure the segment DHCP ip-helper

questions.question_text:
A cloud administrator is tasked with creating a new network segment in the software-defined data center that utilizes the corporate DHCP server to provide IP addresses.
What is the proper sequence to create the required network segments?

choices.B: Multiple vCenter instances in the same VMware Cloud software-defined data center (SDDC) or on-premises data center.
choices.A: Only a single vCenter instance in the on-premises data center or VMware Cloud software-defined data center (SDDC).
choices.D: Only a single vCenter instance in the VMware Cloud software-defined data center (SDDC) or multiple vCenter instances in the on-premises data center.
choices.C: Multiple vCenter instances in the same VMware Cloud software-defined data center (SDDC) or only a single vCenter in the on-premises data center.

questions.question_text: When configuring VMware Cloud Disaster Recovery (VCDR), with what can protection groups and disaster recovery plans be associated?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
"The members of a single protection group must share the same vCenter"

Selected Answer: B
VMware Cloud Disaster Recovery (VCDR) allows you to group and protect virtual machines (VMs) from multiple vCenter servers. This flexibility is beneficial for organizations managing virtual environments with several vCenter instances.

Selected Answer: D
B. Multiple vCenter instances in the same VMware Cloud software-defined data center (SDDC) or on-premises data center.

I think it's A.
Each DR plan protects a single vSphere protected site.
https://vmc.techzone.vmware.com/resource/protection-groups-and-recovery-plans-vcdr#perform-a-failover

Selected Answer: A
My answer is A.
I believe that the virtual machine must select one of the vCenters, and it is not possible to specify multiple vCenters at the same time.

comments.content: the question is what can protection groups be associated with, not what can members of a protection group be associated with. VCDR protection groups can fail over to any vcenter instance in AWS

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
I think it's A
"The members of a single protection group must share the same vCenter"
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Cloud-Disaster-Recovery/services/vmware-cloud-disaster-recovery/GUID-8AE1DC05-46D1-410C-99F6-7687FEB876B5.html

A: ? "Each DR plan protects a single vSphere protected site. "
https://vmc.techzone.vmware.com/resource/protection-groups-and-recovery-plans-vcdr#executing-a-disaster-recovery-plan
